active_learning.discussion_prompt: Discuss the trade-offs between deep specialization in cybersecurity roles and broad cross-training for personnel redundancy. How might overemphasizing cross-training dilute expertise, and what strategies can balance this in a high-threat environment? Use examples from NIST CSF 2.0 Govern functions.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Business Continuity Planning. Topic: 'Cross-Training and Personnel Redundancy Programs' (Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Security And Risk Management > Business Continuity Planning > Continuity and Recovery Strategies > Business Continuity Strategies > Cross-Training and Personnel Redundancy Programs). Optimized Content (incorporating voter priorities: completed NIST CSF 2.0 - GV.OC-06 for workforce resilience; NICE Framework implicit via SP 800-181 Rev1 competency mappings; added sources; concise intro; implementation example; clarified implicit NICE reference): Concise Intro: Cross-training and personnel redundancy prevent personnel SPOFs, ensuring cybersecurity operational continuity and resilience. Core Concepts: Cross-Training (multi-role training, e.g., analysts learn forensics); Personnel Redundancy (multiple backups per function); SPOF (key person risk); Continuity/Resilience (sustained ops post-disruption). Frameworks: NIST CSF 2.0 (Govern: GV.OC-06 - Plan for resilient workforce with redundancy); NIST SP 800-181 Rev1 NICE Framework (implicit: maps competencies for cross-skilling). Sources: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-181r1.pdf; https://www.nist.gov/cyberframework/cybersecurity-framework-20. Active Learning Integration: Weave in prompts/examples from [active_learning]. Output ONLY a JSON array of 50 flashcards, each matching schema. No extras.
